simplified: Your dreams might show you new ideas about things you didn't know you were thinking about. Common dreams like flying or falling, your teeth falling out or being naked in public probably mean something similar for most people. But to understand what they really mean for you, you need to connect them to what happens and how you feel in your everyday life.
original: Your dreams might show you all kinds of insights into things that you didn't realise you were thinking about. Common dreams like being able to fly or falling, your teeth falling out or having no clothes on in a public place probably mean something similar in most people. But the key to understanding exactly what they mean to you is to connect them to the events and feelings in your daily life.

simplified: There are about 35,000 wild dogs living on the streets of Moscow. Some dogs were born on the streets. Other dogs were pets, but their owners left them. Some dogs live alone and some live in groups. In 2010, scientists studied these dogs. They found that the dogs learned to live well in the city. The dogs know it is safer to cross the street with people. Some dogs can understand traffic lights.
original: One of the most interesting cases of wild animals living in a city are the wild dogs of Moscow. In Moscow, there are approximately 35,000 wild dogs living on the streets. Some of the dogs were born wild, while others are pets that have been abandoned by their owners. Some dogs live alone and others live in packs. In 2010, scientists studied the dogs and found that the dogs have adapted remarkably successfully to urban life. They have learned that it is safer to cross the street with people and some dogs appear to understand traffic lights.

simplified: Wonder is New Yorker RJ Palacio's first book. On her website, she says that the idea for the book came to her after seeing a girl with face problems on the street one day. Wonder has sold very well in the United States and has already won several prizes. Many schools are using it to start talks about bullying, friendship and what it's like to be different. A movie is being made, and many people, including me, are waiting excitedly to see what RJ Palacio writes next.
original: Wonder is New Yorker RJ Palacio's first novel. On her website, she explains that the idea for the book came to her after seeing a girl with facial deformities on the street one day. Wonder has been a bestseller in the United States and has already won several awards. Many schools are using it as a starting point for discussions about bullying, friendship and what it's like to be different. A film version is being made, and many, including me, are waiting eagerly to see what RJ Palacio writes next.

simplified: Chloe has two pet rats, Zena and Roxy. Chloe knows they are not normal pets. Many times, people say rats are dirty. Chloe tells them that rats are not dirty and they are very good pets if you take care of them well. But she understands why people don't like rats. Chloe didn't like rats before too. Then her friend Martin showed her his pet rats. She saw that rats are loving and smart animals. Last year, one of Martin's rats had babies. Chloe wanted to have two of them.
original: Chloe has two pet rats, Zena and Roxy. Chloe knows they're not typical pets and she has lost count of the times she's patiently tried to explain to people that rats aren't dirty and they make fantastic pets if you look after them correctly. But she understands why people react badly. She didn't like rats either until her friend Martin showed her his pet rats and she saw how affectionate and intelligent they were. Last year, when one of Martin's rats had babies, Chloe decided she'd like to have two of them.

simplified: Cape Town can be a dangerous place for baboons. Some baboons get hurt or die in car accidents. Others die when they touch electric wires while playing. Baboons are animals that might disappear forever if we don't protect them. To save the baboons and stop problems between people and baboons, the city has workers called Baboon Monitors. These workers chase baboons away from the city or catch them and take them to the countryside. This plan works sometimes, but it is difficult to stop baboons from coming back to the city. The baboons come back because they think the city is a place where they can find food easily.
original: Cape Town can be a dangerous place for baboons. Some have been injured or killed in car accidents and others have been electrocuted as they played with electric cables. Baboons are an endangered species and to save them and minimise conflicts between humans and baboons, the city council has employed a team of Baboon Monitors. The monitors' job is to chase baboons out of urban areas or catch them and release them in the countryside. This policy has had some success, though it is proving hard to stop baboons from coming back to the city once they see it as a source of easy food.

simplified: I work for a big computer company around the world, but their main office is in America, so I do all my work on my computer at home. This means that I don't lose time traveling to work or talking about small things with other workers. I work on different projects, and I can choose when to work. This is very good for me because I can easily stop working when my children need me to go to their school shows or when I need to go to the dentist. The bad thing is that I don't have fixed work hours, so I often work until late at night, sometimes I don't eat dinner because I want to finish my work.
original: I work for a global IT company, but because their headquarters is in the States, I do all my work online from home. That means that I don't waste time commuting or making idle chit-chat with colleagues. I work on a project basis, and this flexibility is very valuable to me because it means that I can easily take some time off when my children need me to go to their school performances or if I need to schedule an appointment with the dentist. The downside is that without clear office hours, I tend to work well into the evening, sometimes skipping dinner to finish a task.

simplified: In the 1990s, graffiti continued but street art also became very popular around the world. Some artists wanted to talk about politics. They made art about war and unfair treatment of people. Other street artists just wanted to make beautiful art. In South America, many street artists worked in poor areas. They painted grey city walls with bright colours to make them more beautiful.
original: In the 1990s, graffiti continued but there was also an explosion in street art around the world. Some artists wanted to make political points and produced art that tried to make people think about war, inequality and discrimination. Other street artists were more concerned with producing beautiful, attractive work. In South America, many street artists went to work in poor areas adding colour, life and beauty to grey, city walls.

simplified: Social media, magazines and shop windows show people many things to buy every day, and British people are buying more clothes and shoes than ever before. Shopping on the internet means it is easy for people to buy without thinking, while big clothing companies sell such cheap clothes that people can throw them away after wearing them only two or three times.
original: Social media, magazines and shop windows bombard people daily with things to buy, and British consumers are buying more clothes and shoes than ever before. Online shopping means it is easy for customers to buy without thinking, while major brands offer such cheap clothes that they can be treated like disposable items – worn two or three times and then thrown away.

simplified: Sam looked at the sun and saw dust from a car going to the Big House. It was hard to see because the sun was very bright. The horses moved around and hit flies with their tails. They didn't care that their owner was visiting for the first time in ten months. Sam waited. Mr Carter only came here when he really had to, and Sam was happy about that. If he stayed away from his boss, he could keep his job longer. Mr Carter cleaned the water from his neck because he was hot. His shirt was wet in many places that looked like shapes on a map. His skin was getting red from the June sun. You could see he usually stayed inside - he looked like a man who made money while other people did the hard work.
original: Sam squinted against the sun at the distant dust trail raked up by the car on its way up to the Big House. The horses kicked and flicked their tails at flies, not caring about their owner's first visit in ten months. Sam waited. Mr Carter didn't come out here unless he had to, which was just fine by Sam. The more he kept out of his boss's way, the longer he'd have a job. Mr, Carter wiped the sweat from the back of his neck. The damp patches on his shirt drew together like shapes in an atlas. His skin was already turning ruddy in the June sun. Otherwise he had the indoor tan of a man that made money while other people did the work.

simplified: People in Berlin, Germany said that killing pigs was too cruel. Hunters and animal lovers had big arguments about this. Because of the protests, the city decided to try peaceful ways to stop the pigs. Now they don't shoot them. Instead, they built fences and made a law that people cannot feed the pigs. We don't know if this will work yet. It might be difficult because winters are warmer now, so there are more pigs than before.
original: Many city residents in Berlin, Germany complained that shooting pigs was unnecessarily cruel and there were heated arguments between hunters and animal lovers. In response to protests, the city council decided to take more peaceful action against pigs. Instead of shooting them, they have put up fences and made it illegal to feed the pigs. Time will tell if this strategy works, though it may be a losing battle as warmer winters mean that pig numbers are greater than in the past.

simplified: An important idea for the Hunger Games book comes from Suzanne's love of old Greek stories. When she was a child, one of her favourite stories was about Theseus and the Minotaur. In this story, the city of Athens must do what Crete says, but the people from Athens fight back. Because of this, Minos the king of Crete makes the people from Athens send seven boys and seven girls to Crete every year. The young people are put into a maze and eaten by a monster that lives there called the Minotaur. But one of the young people, named Theseus, fights the Minotaur and kills it. Suzanne thinks Katniss Everdeen is like a future Theseus.
original: An important inspiration for the Hunger Games book comes from Suzanne's love of classical Greek mythology. When she was a child, one of her favourite stories was Theseus and the Minotaur. In this story the city of Athens is ruled by Crete, but the Athenians rebel. As a punishment, Minos the king of Crete forces the Athenians to send seven boys and seven girls to Crete every year. The youths are thrown into the labyrinth and eaten by a monster that lives there called the Minotaur. But one of the youths, named Theseus, fights the Minotaur and kills it. Suzanne sees Katniss Everdeen as a futuristic Theseus.

simplified: By bringing people and animals together, zoos can teach people about saving animals and make people want to protect animals and the places where they live. Some zoos give a safe home to animals that were hurt in circuses, or pets that their owners left behind. Zoos also do important studies about things like how animals act and how to help sick animals get better.
original: By bringing people and animals together, zoos have the potential to educate the public about conservation issues and inspire people to protect animals and their habitats. Some zoos provide a safe environment for animals which have been mistreated in circuses, or pets which have been abandoned. Zoos also carry out important research into subjects like animal behaviour and how to treat illnesses.

simplified: A different idea is starting because people don't want to buy so many things – the 'buy nothing' idea. This idea started in Canada in the early 1990s and then went to the US. There, it became a way to say no to spending too much money and buying too many things on Black Friday and Cyber Monday during Thanksgiving weekend. On Buy Nothing Day, people organize different kinds of protests and cut up their credit cards. During the year, Buy Nothing groups organize the exchange and repair of things they already have.
original: A different trend is springing up in opposition to consumerism – the 'buy nothing' trend. The idea originated in Canada in the early 1990s and then moved to the US, where it became a rejection of the overspending and overconsumption of Black Friday and Cyber Monday during Thanksgiving weekend. On Buy Nothing Day people organise various types of protests and cut up their credit cards. Throughout the year, Buy Nothing groups organise the exchange and repair of items they already own.

simplified: Is graffiti art or vandalism? This depends on what you think, but in many countries, writing or painting on public or private buildings is considered vandalism. Vandalism means damaging other people's things. Many street artists have been stopped by the police and some have had to pay money as punishment. Many city governments complain about the high cost of cleaning graffiti off buildings, buses and trains.
original: Is graffiti art or vandalism? This depends on your point of view, but in many countries, writing or painting on public or private property is considered vandalism. Many street artists have been stopped by the police and some have had to pay fines. Many city councils complain about the high cost of cleaning graffiti off buildings, buses and trains.

simplified: What do people in the art world think about graffiti and street art? Recently, more and more people are starting to see that it has value as art. There have been big shows of street art in art galleries in Paris, London and Los Angeles. The American artist Elura Emerald made a street art show at a New York gallery in 2008. She supported street artists, saying 'artists who paint on the street are just showing their feelings and ideas, not hurting anyone. People should like them and think they are good'.
original: What does the art world think of graffiti and street art? Recently, there has been a growing recognition of its value as an art form. There have been major exhibitions of street art in galleries in Paris, London and Los Angeles. The American artist Elura Emerald organised a street art exhibition at a New York gallery in 2008. She defended street artists, saying 'artists who paint on the street are merely expressing themselves, not hurting anyone. They should be appreciated and celebrated'.

simplified: Most people have four to six dreams every night after they are ten years old. That means about 2,000 dreams every year. So when a person is 80 years old, they might have had 140,000 dreams in their life. We forget most of our dreams - maybe 95 to 99 out of 100 dreams. But we still remember a few thousand dreams in our whole life. Sometimes we dream about something, and then the same thing happens in real life later. This can happen by chance, especially if we dream about things that happen often in everyday life. So it's not strange when a dream and real life are similar.
original: If most people have four to six dreams every night after the age of ten, that's as many as 2,000 dreams per year. So, by the time they reach 80 years old the average person might have had 140,000 dreams. Even if we forget 95–99 per cent of our dreams, that's still a few thousand remembered dreams across a lifetime. It's not too difficult to believe that, by coincidence, a dream event is followed by a real-life event that's similar to it, especially if the subject of the dream is something that happens often in everyday life.

simplified: The Hunger Games happens in the future, after North America was destroyed. The country is called Panem and has twelve poor areas called districts. A rich place called the Capitol controls all of them. The Capitol has all the power in the country. Each district must make different things for the Capitol. District 12, where the story starts, gives all the coal to the country. There was a thirteenth district before, but they fought against the Capitol and the Capitol destroyed them.
original: The Hunger Games takes place in the future, after the destruction of North America. The country is called Panem and is made up of twelve poor districts governed by the wealthy Capitol. The Capitol holds absolute power over the nation. Each district is responsible for producing different things for the Capitol. District 12, where the story begins, provides all the coal for the country. There used to be a thirteenth district but they rebelled against the Capitol in the past and were destroyed.

simplified: Sometimes wild animals come into cities to look for food. In Cape Town, South Africa, baboons have started coming into areas where people live at the edge of the city to eat. They open rubbish bins and eat fruit from gardens. Some brave baboons have even come into people's houses and taken food from kitchen cupboards and fridges! Baboons can be angry and dangerous and have attacked many pet animals, so many people in the city don't want them there.
original: Often wild animals come into cities to look for food. In Cape Town, South Africa, baboons have started coming into residential areas on the edge of the city to feed. They open rubbish bins and eat fruit from gardens and orchards. Some brave baboons have even come into people's houses and taken food from kitchen cupboards and fridges! Baboons can be aggressive and have attacked a lot of pet animals, so understandably, many city residents don't welcome their presence.

simplified: Many bridge accidents happen when people are building the bridge. These accidents often happen because the engineers make a mistake, like doing the math wrong. The bridge falls down because it is too heavy, and this can kill the workers who are on the bridge when it happens.
original: A large number of bridge accidents occur during the construction of the bridge itself. These accidents are often due to an error made by the engineers, such as a miscalculation. The bridge collapses under its own weight, and this can be deadly for the workers on it at the time.

simplified: George Lucas was one of the first movie directors to build his story on the 17 steps of the hero's journey. Usually the hero starts the story living a normal life, but something happens that asks them to go on an adventure that changes everything. At the beginning of Star Wars, Luke lives a normal life with his aunt and uncle, fixing robots. When he finds Princess Leia's message to Obi-Wan Kenobi inside the robot R2D2, it is 'the call to adventure' that starts the hero on his trip.
original: George Lucas was one of the early film directors to directly base his story on the 17 stages of the hero's journey. Typically the hero starts the story living an ordinary life, but something happens that calls them to an adventure that changes everything. At the beginning of Star Wars, Luke lives an ordinary life with his aunt and uncle, repairing robots. When he finds Princess Leia's message to Obi-Wan Kenobi inside the robot R2D2, it is 'the call to adventure' that starts the hero on his journey.

simplified: Another idea to protect Earth from a dangerous space rock is to break it into pieces using a nuclear bomb. This sounds like something from a movie, and it was in the 1998 movie Armageddon, but HAMMER is a real plan from NASA. HAMMER means "Hypervelocity Asteroid Mitigation Mission for Emergency Response." The plan uses very heavy rockets that weigh eight tons. Scientists would send these rockets to hit a space rock that is coming toward Earth. They hope this would push the space rock away from Earth. If the space rock is too close to Earth and this plan cannot work, the rockets would carry nuclear bombs to break the space rock into small pieces.
original: Another suggested defence against a PHA on course to hit Earth is to blow it up using a nuclear weapon. It may sound like a plot from a film, and it was the subject of the 1998 film Armageddon, but the Hypervelocity Asteroid Mitigation Mission for Emergency Response (HAMMER) is a genuine NASA proposal. The eight-ton rockets would be fired at an approaching asteroid with the hope of bumping it off course. If the asteroid was too close to Earth for this plan to work, the rockets would carry nuclear bombs to blow it up instead.

simplified: According to Campbell, the hero first says no to the adventure, but a teacher appears who helps them and they decide to 'cross the threshold' and go into the 'special world' where the adventure happens. The next part is about passing tests, fighting bad people and meeting friends as the hero gets ready to face their biggest problem. For Luke the teacher is, of course, Obi-Wan, the friends are Han Solo and the robots R2D2 and C3PO and the bad person is Darth Vader inside the special world of the Death Star.
original: According to Campbell, the hero at first refuses the call to adventure, but a mentor appears who helps them and they decide to 'cross the threshold' and travel into the 'special world' where the adventure happens. The next stage consists of passing tests, fighting enemies and meeting friends as the hero prepares to face their biggest challenge. For Luke the mentor is, of course, Obi-Wan, the friends are Han Solo and the robots R2D2 and C3PO and the enemy is Darth Vader inside the special world of the Death Star.

simplified: Things that people don't use much may seem useless to some, but could be helpful to others. When the internet started, online groups found a way to make money from sharing those unused things. Using websites and social media groups that help people buy and sell used goods, it is now easier than ever for people to share things with each other. And this is called the sharing economy.
original: Underutilised items may seem useless to some, but could be an asset to others. With the advent of the internet, online communities have figured out a way to generate profit from the sharing of those underused assets. Using websites and social media groups that facilitate the buying and selling of second-hand goods, it is now easier than ever for peer-to-peer sharing activities to take place. And this is known as the sharing economy.

simplified: Around 200-300 years ago, two main ideas about dreams became popular. One idea was that the things we see in our dreams show things that are hidden in our mind. Freud (a famous doctor who studied the mind) believed that if we understand what dreams are telling us, we can understand our hidden feelings and the problems they cause. However, the other idea was the opposite. It said that dreams are just a mix of random things happening in the brain while it's putting together memories and things from the day. When we wake up, we try to understand these random pictures and feelings and put them into some kind of story.
original: Around the 18th and 19th centuries two main ideas about dreams became popular. One was the idea that the things we see in our dreams represent things hidden from our conscious mind. Freud believed that if we understand what dreams are telling us, we can understand our hidden feelings and the problems they cause. However, the other theory was the opposite. It said that dreams are just a collection of random activity in the brain while it's organising memories and events from the day. When we wake up, we try to make sense of these random images and feelings and put them into some sort of story.

simplified: I work for myself and don't have a boss. This is great because I can choose what I do and how I use my time. At first, I was working at home, but I found it really hard to think clearly about my work. There were too many things that took my attention away: cleaning the house, making another cup of tea, my family asking me to help them with different things. So I started to go to a coffee shop near my house to work, but the internet wasn't very good and I drank too much coffee. Finally, I decided to pay money to use a desk in a shared office with five other people who also work for themselves. I liked putting on work clothes to go to work in the morning and being able to work well in an office.
original: I'm a freelancer and work for myself. This is great because I am in control of what I do and how I spend my time. At first, I was working from home, but I found it really hard to concentrate. There were just too many distractions around: housework that needed doing, another cup of tea, my family members wanting my attention for various things. So I started to go to a nearby café to work, but the Wi-Fi connection wasn't ideal and I found myself drinking too much coffee. In the end, I decided to rent a desk in a co-working space with five other freelancers like myself. I liked getting dressed to go to work in the morning and being able to focus in an office environment.

simplified: Whether NASA can find the other medium-sized NEOs depends on getting money to build NEOCam, a 0.5-metre space telescope that would use infrared light to find asteroids. NEOs are Near-Earth Objects - rocks in space that come close to Earth. If NASA got the money, it could probably reach its goal in ten years. After finding these objects, the planetary defence team would still need to work out how to protect the planet from being hit by the really dangerous asteroids – the PHAs. PHAs are Potentially Hazardous Asteroids - space rocks that could hit Earth and cause serious damage.
original: Whether NASA can find the remaining middle-sized NEOs depends on getting the money to build NEOCam, a 0.5-metre space telescope which would use infrared light to locate asteroids. If it did get the money, it could probably achieve its goal in ten years. Once logged, the planetary defence team would still need to work out how to defend the planet against being hit by the truly worrying asteroids – the PHAs.

simplified: The 'buy nothing' trend has now reached influencers on social media. These people usually share posts about clothes and make-up that they tell people to buy. Some YouTube stars now tell their followers not to buy anything at all for long periods - sometimes a whole year. Two friends in Canada spent a year trying to buy only food. For the first three months, they learned how to live without buying things like phones, computers, clothes or things for their home. After that, they stopped paying for services too - like getting their hair cut, eating at restaurants or buying gas for their cars. In one year, they saved $55,000.
original: The 'buy nothing' trend has now reached influencers on social media who usually share posts of clothing and make-up that they recommend for people to buy. Some YouTube stars now encourage their viewers not to buy anything at all for periods as long as a year. Two friends in Canada spent a year working towards buying only food. For the first three months they learned how to live without buying electrical goods, clothes or things for the house. For the next stage, they gave up services, for example haircuts, eating out at restaurants or buying petrol for their cars. In one year, they'd saved $55,000.

simplified: Religion is important to Pi. His family follows Hinduism, but he wants to learn about other religions too. He becomes friends with a Christian priest and a Muslim baker. Everyone is surprised when Pi says he is Hindu, Muslim and Christian at the same time. His family and teachers tell him to pick only one religion, but Pi says no. He says 'I just want to love God'. After that, his family and teachers let him decide about religion by himself.
original: Religion is important to Pi. Though his family is Hindu, he is curious about other religions and he makes friends with a Christian priest and a Muslim baker. To everyone's surprise, Pi declares himself to be simultaneously Hindu, Muslim and Christian. When his family and teachers ask him to choose just one religion, Pi refuses, saying 'I just want to love God'. From that moment, his family and teachers decide to let him make his own mind up about religion.

simplified: Some people think writing your dreams down can help you have lucid dreams. Lucid dreams are dreams where you know you are dreaming and you can control what happens in your dreams. So, maybe you can change a scary dream into a nice dream, or you can control your dream like making a movie. Then, you won't just try to understand what your dreams mean - you will make them yourself! But you might still want to have some normal dreams that show you what you are really thinking about.
original: Some people think writing your dreams down can open your mind to lucid dreaming. Lucid dreams are dreams where you're not only aware you're dreaming but you can make decisions to affect the events of your dreams. So, maybe you can turn a nightmare into a safe-feeling dream, or you can direct the plot of your dream like a film director. Then, instead of just working out the meaning of your dreams, you'll be creating them, though you might want to continue having some dreams that allow your subconscious to tell you what's on your mind!

simplified: People might not know they are part of the throw-away clothing problem because they give their old clothes to charity shops. But charity shops can't sell all those old clothes. 'Fast fashion' means cheap clothes that go out of style very quickly. These clothes are often too bad quality to use again, and people don't want to buy them in second-hand shops. Very large amounts end up in the trash, and many clothes that charity shops can't sell are sent to other countries. This causes more money problems and harm to the environment.
original: People might not realise they are part of the disposable clothing problem because they donate their unwanted clothes to charities. But charity shops can't sell all those unwanted clothes. 'Fast fashion' goes out of fashion as quickly as it came in and is often too poor quality to recycle; people don't want to buy it second-hand. Huge quantities end up being thrown away, and a lot of clothes that charities can't sell are sent abroad, causing even more economic and environmental problems.

simplified: Some people today love to do difficult and exciting trips. They go from one challenge to another challenge. Meagan McGrath is from Canada. She has climbed the highest mountain on each continent (the seven biggest areas of land in the world). She has also ridden a bike across Canada and run a very long race in the Sahara Desert when it was 45ºC - very, very hot. But her most amazing trip was skiing to the South Pole (the bottom of the Earth where it is always very cold). On the first day, she fell into a glacier (a big piece of ice) and people had to help her get out. Many people would have stopped trying after that happened, but Meagan decided to continue. She reached the South Pole forty days later. She pulled a sledge (a thing that moves on snow) with a tent and all her food behind her. She did this in very cold weather and ice storms.
original: Not content with one amazing trip, some of today's adventurers go from challenge to challenge. Meagan McGrath from Canada has climbed the highest mountain on each continent, ridden a bike across Canada and run a long-distance race in the Sahara Desert in 45ºC heat. But perhaps her most remarkable journey was a skiing trip to the South Pole. On the first day, she fell into a glacier and had to be rescued. Many of us would have given up at that point, but Meagan decided to carry on. She reached the South Pole forty days later, having pulled a sledge with a tent and all her food behind her through freezing conditions and ice storms.

simplified: Blek le Rat started by painting rats on the walls of his home city, Paris. Now, he tries to make people think about different problems in society. He paints pictures of people who have no homes in big cities to help people living there think about this problem.
original: Blek le Rat started out painting rats on the walls of his home city, Paris. Nowadays, he tries to make people think about different social issues and problems. He paints pictures of homeless people in big cities to encourage residents to think about the problem of homelessness.

simplified: In some places, local governments have tried to help artists not to paint graffiti anywhere they want on walls. Instead, they let artists work in special areas. Taiwan is one place like this. There are 'graffiti zones' where artists can paint and write on walls freely. In São Paulo in Brazil, the city government has even let some graffiti artists paint on the city's underground trains.
original: In some areas, councils have tried to encourage artists not to paint graffiti randomly on walls by allowing them to work in designated areas. Taiwan is one such place and there are 'graffiti zones' where artists are free to paint and write on walls. In São Paulo in Brazil, the city council has even allowed some graffiti artists to paint on the city's subway trains.

simplified: Faith47 is from Cape Town in South Africa. She paints big, colourful pictures of people and animals and likes to visit different places. Her work is found on streets, in old empty buildings and on old cars that nobody uses. She likes that most street art does not stay forever and will soon be washed away by rain or cleaned by city workers. For her, this shows how life is always changing with things ending and new things starting.
original: Faith47 is from Cape Town in South Africa. She paints big, colourful pictures of people and animals and likes to explore different locations. Her work is found on pavements, in empty factories and on abandoned cars. She likes the fact that most street art is temporary and will soon be removed by weather or cleaners from the city council. For her, this reflects how life is full of change with its cycle of endings and new beginnings.

simplified: In her old job, Gabriela was used to a workplace where bosses had a lot of power and workers always respected them. Everyone knew their place. In this type of workplace, the bosses make all the important decisions and workers don't usually question them. But her Swedish team was used to a very different workplace where workers often work together with their bosses to find answers and make decisions. Here, bosses act like teachers or helpers who want workers to think for themselves and expect workers to ask questions and give different ideas.
original: In her previous work environment, Gabriela was used to a high power distance culture where power and authority are respected and everyone has their rightful place. In such a culture, leaders make the big decisions and are not often challenged. Her Swedish team, however, were used to working in a low power distance culture where subordinates often work together with their bosses to find solutions and make decisions. Here, leaders act as coaches or mentors who encourage independent thought and expect to be challenged.

simplified: When Gabriela learned about the differences between her culture and her team's culture, she decided to talk openly with them about how they felt about her as their leader. Her team was happy that she asked for their opinions. They told her honestly that they were not used to someone telling them exactly what to do. They liked having more freedom to make their own decisions and be creative. When Gabriela told her team exactly what they needed to do, they felt that she didn't believe they could do their job well. They understood that Gabriela felt hurt when they disagreed with her decisions or wanted to change them. They were able to explain that this was the normal way they had always worked.
original: When Gabriela became aware of the cultural differences between her and her team, she took the initiative to have an open conversation with them about their feelings about her leadership. Pleased to be asked for their thoughts, Gabriela's team openly expressed that they were not used to being told what to do. They enjoyed having more room for initiative and creative freedom. When she told her team exactly what she needed them to do, they felt that she didn't trust them to do their job well. They realised that Gabriela was taking it personally when they tried to challenge or make changes to her decisions, and were able to explain that it was how they'd always worked.

simplified: Os Gêmeos are two brothers from São Paulo. They are twins - this means they were born on the same day and look the same. They paint many different things. Sometimes they paint small writing on walls. Sometimes they paint very big, colourful pictures of people on the sides of buildings. Their paintings are often so big that they need special machines called cranes to help them reach high places. In 2007, they painted a whole castle in Scotland.
original: Os Gêmeos are identical twin brothers from São Paulo. They paint everything from tags to huge, colourful pictures of people on the sides of buildings. Their work is often so big that they need cranes to help them work. In 2007, they covered the whole of a castle in Scotland with paint.

simplified: People have been painting and writing on walls for a very long time. Long, long ago, people in Africa and Europe painted pictures of animals and people inside caves. People have also found writing and pictures on old buildings in Greece, Italy, Syria and Iraq. In Pompeii, an old Roman town, archaeologists (people who study old things) found many examples of writing on walls in Latin (an old language). These writings were about religion, politics and love, and some were even magic spells!
original: People have been painting and writing on walls throughout history. In prehistoric times, people in Africa and Europe used to paint pictures of animals and people in caves. Graffiti has been found on buildings at ancient sites in Greece, Italy, Syria and Iraq. In the Roman town of Pompeii, archaeologists have found numerous examples of graffiti written in Latin. These include religious, political and romantic messages, and even some magic spells!

simplified: Have you ever dreamed of climbing Mount Everest or walking to the South Pole? If so, you're not alone. Every year, thousands of people try to climb the world's highest mountains or walk across continents. Unlike the explorers of the past who used maps and compasses, today's adventurers travel with modern technology like GPS (a system that shows your location) and satellite phones (special phones that work anywhere in the world). Many adventurers love nature and use their travels to help tell people about environmental problems, while others want to help people in need and collect money for charities.
original: Have you ever dreamt of climbing Mount Everest or walking to the South Pole? If so, you're not alone. Every year, thousands of people try to climb the world's highest mountains or walk across continents. Unlike the explorers of the past who used maps and compasses, today's adventurers travel with modern technology like GPS and satellite phones. Many adventurers are nature lovers who use their travels to help raise awareness about a range of environmental issues, while others are keen to help people in need and raise money for charities.

simplified: The first is DART – the Double Asteroid Redirection Test. Scientists plan to test DART on the moon of a space rock called Didymos. 'Didymoon' is 150 metres wide. It goes around its bigger space rock which is 800 metres wide. Scientists hope that when DART hits Didymoon, it will push it out of its path. Then telescopes on Earth will be able to see this change.
original: The first is DART – the Double Asteroid Redirection Test. Plans are scheduled to test DART on the moon of an asteroid called Didymos. 'Didymoon' is 150 metres wide, orbiting its 800-metre mother, and hopefully the impact of DART will knock it out of its orbit enough for Earth-based telescopes to pick up.

simplified: The main character of the story is a sixteen year old girl called Katniss Everdeen. Her father died in an accident at work in the mines and now she has to find food for her family. She goes hunting in the forest near District 12 with her friend Gale and becomes very good at using a bow and arrow. When her younger sister, Prim, is picked to fight in the games, Katniss says she will go instead of her. The other person from District 12 who has to fight is a boy named Peeta and Katniss soon has difficult feelings about him.
original: The heroine of the story, a sixteen year old girl called Katniss Everdeen, has lost her father in a mining accident and has to provide food for her family. She hunts in the woods around District 12 with her friend Gale and becomes very skilful with a bow and arrow. When her younger sister, Prim, is chosen as one of the tributes, Katniss volunteers to go instead. The other tribute from District 12 is a boy named Peeta and Katniss soon finds herself in a complicated relationship with him.

simplified: Write about your dreams and you will remember more things about them. Think about the people and places in your dream because they are important too. After one week, you will be surprised how much you wrote. Now you can connect your dreams to things that happen in your real life and how you feel.
original: Writing about your dreams will mean you start to remember more details about the dream, so think about the people and place where the dream happened as they might add to the meaning too. Over the period of a week you'll be surprised how much you've written down. Now you can start connecting your dreams to the events and feelings in your daily life.

simplified: In the past, people made most bridges from wood. Wood bridges could catch fire very easily. This was a big problem for old train bridges. When trains moved on the tracks, the steel wheels and steel tracks made sparks. Sometimes these sparks made the wooden bridge catch fire. When this happened, the whole bridge could burn down completely.
original: Historically, more bridges were made of wood and were much more susceptible to fire. This was particularly true of old-fashioned train bridges, where the spark created by the steel wheels and steel tracks could sometimes cause a bridge to catch fire and burn to the ground.

simplified: We cannot know how street art will change in the future, but we can see some new things happening. Most street artists are young people who paint in their city or area where they live. But now, more and more street artists are going to different countries and working all over the world. Other artists are using the internet to talk to each other and share pictures of their work. Also, the art world is starting to accept street art as real art. We don't know what will happen to street art in the future, but we can be sure that it will continue to exist!
original: It is impossible to know how street art will develop in the future but certain trends are emerging. While most street artists are young people who paint in their city or neighbourhood, more and more street artists are travelling and working around the globe. Other artists are using the internet to talk to each other and share photos of their work. Also, the art world is giving more recognition to street art as a legitimate art form. Although we don't know what will happen to street art in the future, we can be sure that it is here to stay!

simplified: Suzanne Collines always feels sad when she watches news about wars on TV. When she was a child, her father was a pilot for the US Air Force and he went to fight in Vietnam. Her mother wanted to keep her safe, so she did not tell her what was happening in the war. But Suzanne still saw the war news on TV and she knew her dad was there. She was very scared.
original: Suzanne Collines has always found news programmes of wars upsetting. When she was a child, her father was a pilot in the US Air Force and he fought in Vietnam. Her mother tried to protect her by not telling her what was happening in the war, but she still saw news programmes about the war and knew that her dad was there. It was a very frightening experience for her.

simplified:
Two big companies, PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) and Deloitte, did surveys about work. A survey is when you ask many people questions to learn about something.

In the PwC survey, more than 40,000 people answered questions. Some people were millennials (people born between 1983 and 1993) and some were not millennials. They asked questions about workplace culture (how people work together), communication (how people talk to each other), working styles (different ways people work), pay structure (how much money people get), career development (how to get better jobs), and work-life balance (having time for work and personal life).

In the Deloitte survey, more than 10,000 millennials answered questions. They asked about what millennials think about good and bad things that can happen in the difficult world of work.
original: In a global survey conducted by PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC), more than 40,000 millennial (born between 1983 and 1993) and non-millennial responses were collected on the topics of workplace culture, communication and working styles, pay structure, career development, work–life balance, etc. In a separate global survey conducted by Deloitte, more than 10,000 millennials participated in a study about their perceptions of the threats and opportunities in the complex world of work.

simplified: Erik Weihenmayer is from the United States and he loves adventure. He has ridden a bike through the deserts of Morocco, used a kayak to go through the Grand Canyon and climbed Mount Everest. What is amazing is that Erik cannot see - he has been blind since he was 13 years old. When he is not traveling, he tries to help people with disabilities to have active lives. He takes groups of young blind people on trips to climb mountains.
original: Erik Weihenmayer from the United States is a multi-adventurer. He's ridden a bike through the deserts of Morocco, kayaked through the Grand Canyon and climbed Everest. Amazingly, Erik has been blind since the age of 13. Apart from his travels, he tries to encourage people with disabilities to live active lives and takes groups of young blind people on climbing expeditions.

simplified: Online websites are giving people a chance to make some money quickly. For example, busy parents before did not want to set up a table at the local market or car boot sale to sell their children's old things. But now with online shops on the internet, parents can sell baby clothes that their children wore only a few times and that are now too small. They can also sell expensive baby pushchairs and other baby things they bought. This way, they can get some money back.
original: Democratised online platforms are providing a chance for people to make a quick buck or two. To give an example, busy parents previously might not have bothered with setting up a stall at the local market or car boot sale to sell their children's old equipment, but with online marketplaces, parents are now able to sell on those hardly worn baby clothes that their children have outgrown and the expensive pushchairs and baby equipment they have invested in, so as to put some cash back into their pockets.

simplified: Pi and Richard Parker spend 227 days in the small boat. They go through being very hungry, sick and very tired. They live through bad storms and the very hot sun over the Pacific Ocean, but they stay alive. Sometimes, Pi feels better because of his three religions, but other times he feels very alone and sad. Finally, they can see the coast of Mexico far away and everything changes. It would be wrong to tell you the ending, so you will have to read the book yourself to find out what happens to Pi and Richard Parker when they can see land.
original: Pi and Richard Parker spend 227 days in the lifeboat. They live through hunger, illness and exhaustion. They endure violent storms and the burning heat of the Pacific sun, but somehow they survive. At times, Pi finds comfort in his three religions, but at other times he is overcome with loneliness and despair. Finally, the Mexican coast appears on the horizon and everything changes. It would be a shame to give away the ending, so you will have to read the book yourself to find out what happens to Pi and Richard Parker once land is in sight.

simplified: Chloe came home from school, made herself a cup of coffee and took it to her bedroom. She had some homework to do, but she could do that later. She wanted to enjoy the quiet time before her parents came home and the house became noisy with talking, television or her dad listening to his favorite jazz music while he made dinner. She liked this time of day too because she could play with her pet rats.
original: Chloe arrived home from school, made herself a cup of coffee and took it up to her bedroom. She had some homework to do, but that could wait for later. She wanted to enjoy the quiet hour before her parents arrived home and the house filled up with the evening sounds of chatter, television or her dad listening to his beloved jazz while he cooked dinner. She liked this time of day too because she could play with her pet rats.

simplified: In 2010, NASA's team that protects Earth from space rocks found and recorded 90 per cent of the asteroids near Earth that are 1km wide. These 'near-Earth objects', or NEOs, are as big as mountains. They include anything within 50 million kilometres of Earth's path around the sun. NASA thinks there are about 50 more to find. NASA says none of the 887 asteroids it knows about are dangerous to Earth.
original: In 2010, the planetary defence team at NASA had identified and logged 90 per cent of the asteroids near Earth measuring 1km wide. These 'near-Earth objects', or NEOs, are the size of mountains and include anything within 50 million kilometres of Earth's orbit. With an estimated 50 left to log, NASA says none of the 887 it knows about are a significant danger to the planet.

simplified: Auggie decides to go to school, but his first day is very difficult. He feels very worried, like all children at a new school. But because his face looks different, it is much harder for him. Other children don't want to sit next to him. They look at him and talk about him quietly. Luckily, he becomes friends with Jack, a boy in his class, and Summer, a girl he talks to at lunch. But school stays difficult. His classmates don't want to touch him because they think they will get sick. During the school year, Auggie has many good and bad times. Then something surprising and scary happens at a school trip that changes everything.
original: Having decided to go to school, Auggie then has to face his first day. Like every child starting at a new school, he is really anxious. But because of the way he looks, it's an agonising experience. Nobody wants to sit next to him and he notices other kids staring at him or talking about him behind their hands. Fortunately, he makes friends with Jack, a boy in his class, and Summer, a girl he chats with at lunch. But it's not just the first day that's hard. Auggie soon learns that his classmates don't want to touch him for fear of catching 'the plague'. As he goes through the school year, Auggie goes through many intense ups and downs till finally an unexpected and traumatic event at a school camp changes things completely.

simplified: The two men looked towards the north side of the land. It went on and on as far as they could see. Even the fences were hard to see from where they were standing. A teenage boy might get bored and angry, but he could not run away on foot from this place. Sam looked at the biggest horse. It was hitting the ground with its feet. Could the boy ride a horse? he thought. A good rider could cause a lot of problems out here, far away from other people. But maybe someone who did not know about horses and wanted to get away from his father could have even bigger problems.
original: The two men looked towards the northern end of the property. It stretched as far as the eye could see. Even the fences were barely visible from where they stood. However bored and rebellious a teenage boy might get, it wasn't possible to escape on foot. Sam looked at the biggest of the horses, kicking at the ground with its heavy hooves. Could the boy ride? he wondered. There was a whole load of trouble a good rider could get into out here, miles away from anyone. But maybe there was even more trouble for someone who knew nothing about horses and wanted to get away from his father.

simplified: More than 4,000 climbers, from thirteen to eighty years old, have reached the top of Everest. Even though climbing tall mountains in very cold weather and bad storms is still very dangerous, the world's best climbers now look for new things to do. Gerlinde Kaltenbrunner from Austria started to love mountain climbing when she was a teenager. When she finished school, she worked as a nurse, but she continued climbing mountains in her free time.
original: Over 4,000 climbers, aged from thirteen to eighty have been to the top of Everest. Though climbing high mountains in freezing conditions and violent storms is still extremely dangerous, the world's best climbers now look for new challenges. Gerlinde Kaltenbrunner from Austria fell in love with mountain climbing as a teenager. When she left school, she worked as a nurse, but kept climbing in her free time.

simplified: After climbing Everest, Gerlinde decided to climb all fourteen of the world's highest mountains (over 8,000 metres high). To make it harder, Gerlinde climbs without extra oxygen to help her breathe. This is dangerous because there is very little oxygen at the top of very high mountains, and this can hurt how your brain and body work. Gerlinde uses her fame as a mountain climber to help a charity that takes care of poor children and children without parents in Nepal.
original: Having climbed Everest, Gerlinde decided to climb all fourteen of the world's 8,000 metre peaks. To increase the challenge, Gerlinde climbs without using oxygen tanks. This is risky as low oxygen levels at the top of high mountains can affect brain and body functioning. Gerlinde uses her fame as a climber to support a charity for poor children and orphans in Nepal.

simplified: If we look at the things we bought in our lives, we can see that we don't use everything we have: the thick warm coat that we thought looked good but we live in a hot country, the old phone that we put away when we bought a new one, the car that we only use on Saturday and Sunday, or the extra bedroom in our house that became a room where we keep old things.
original: If we look around us at the things we have purchased at some point in our lives, we would no doubt notice that not everything we own is being put to good use: the thick woollen coat which we thought looked trendy despite the fact that we live in a tropical country, the smartphone that got put away when we bought ourselves the newest model, the car that only gets used at the weekends, or even the guest room in our house that somehow got turned into a storeroom.

simplified: For a long time and in many different countries, people believed dreams could tell the future. People thought dreams were messages from gods. They believed gods sent dreams to give people special knowledge or to help them understand things. Even now, many people remember when they had a dream about something - like an event, a place, or a person - and then later, the same thing really happened in their life.
original: Throughout history and across cultures, dreams have been associated with prophecy. People thought dreams were messages from the gods, sent to give us knowledge or insight. Even today, many people can recall a time they dreamed about an event, place or person and then, later, the dream came true in real life.

simplified: Some of the biggest and most expensive transportation projects in the world are about building bridges. Bridges are very important connections that help cars, trucks and trains go across water, deep valleys between mountains, or other roads. Because of this, they are one of the most important parts of civil engineering (the work of planning and building roads, bridges and buildings). People watch and check them very carefully, especially when they fall down.
original: Some of the biggest and most expensive transportation projects in the world have involved building bridges. Bridges are crucial links that carry cars, trucks and trains across bodies of water, mountain gorges or other roads. As a result, they are one of the most important aspects of civil engineering and are subject to intense scrutiny, especially when they collapse.

simplified: After weeks of feeling angry and upset, Gabriela sent an email to her Swedish boss about the problems she had with her team. Her boss only asked her if she thought her team was still doing good work, and what she thought would help her work better with her team members. Gabriela thought her boss was not clear enough and didn't feel like he was dealing with the problem in a good way.
original: After weeks of frustration, Gabriela emailed her Swedish manager about the issues she was facing with her team. Her manager simply asked her if she felt her team was still performing, and what she thought would help her better collaborate with her team members. Gabriela found her manager vague and didn't feel as if he was managing the situation satisfactorily.

simplified: Dogs that live in groups have learned that humans like to give food to smaller, prettier dogs. So these dogs are sent to ask for food for all the dogs in the group. Some dogs have even learned to use the city's underground trains to go from one place to another in their area! Scientists don't know how the dogs know when to get off the train. One idea is that they use their very good sense of smell and have learned to know the smells of their favorite places. Another idea is that they have learned to know the names of train stops they hear when someone speaks on the train. Now, people on the trains are so used to seeing dogs on the trains that the dogs can travel without people really noticing them.
original: Dogs that live in packs have learnt that humans are more likely to give food to smaller, cuter dogs so those dogs are sent to beg for food for the whole pack. Some dogs have even learnt to use the city's metro system to get from one part of their territory to another! Scientists are not sure how the dogs know when to get off the train. One idea is that they use their excellent sense of smell and have learnt to recognise the scents of their favourite destinations. Another possibility is that they have learnt to recognise the names of stations they hear in announcements. Either way, metro passengers have now got so used to the sight of dogs on the trains that they travel largely unnoticed by locals.

simplified: Ed Stafford from the UK is the first person to walk along the whole Amazon River. He started by a small river in the Andes mountains of Peru and arrived where the river meets the sea in Brazil. This took two years and four months. He walked 6,000 kilometres. The Amazon rainforest has dangerous snakes that can kill you, crocodiles and jaguars, so Ed was always in danger. Luckily, he lived and was only hurt by thousands of mosquito and ant bites.
original: Ed Stafford from the UK is the first person to walk the length of the Amazon River. He started by a small stream in the Andes mountains of Peru and arrived at the river's mouth in Brazil, two years and four months later, having walked 6,000 kilometres. The Amazon rainforest is home to poisonous snakes, crocodiles and jaguars, so Ed was in constant danger. Luckily, he survived with nothing worse than a few thousand mosquito and ant bites.

simplified: In Britain, the average person spends more than £1,000 on new clothes every year. This is about four per cent of their money. That might not sound like a lot, but this number shows two big problems for people and for the environment. First, many people buy clothes with credit cards (special cards that let you buy things now and pay later). British people owe about £670 per adult to credit card companies. That's 66 per cent of the money they spend on clothes. Also, people are not only spending money they don't have, they're buying things they don't need. Britain throws away 300,000 tons of clothing every year. Most of these clothes go to landfill sites (big holes in the ground where we put rubbish).
original: In Britain, the average person spends more than £1,000 on new clothes a year, which is around four per cent of their income. That might not sound like much, but that figure hides two far more worrying trends for society and for the environment. First, a lot of that consumer spending is via credit cards. British people currently owe approximately £670 per adult to credit card companies. That's 66 per cent of the average wardrobe budget. Also, not only are people spending money they don't have, they're using it to buy things they don't need. Britain throws away 300,000 tons of clothing a year, most of which goes into landfill sites.

simplified: Ed could not do his walk without technology. He used a radio to talk to the people who live in the rainforest. He asked them for food and asked if he could walk through their land. Many of these people came to see him and helped him walk through the most difficult places. While Ed was walking, he wrote a blog. A blog is like a diary on the internet. He wrote about what happened to him every day. Many people were interested in his trip. Ed used this interest to tell people that cutting down the rainforest is bad. He also collected money to help the environment and help children in Brazil and Peru.
original: Ed's walk would have been impossible without technology. He used a radio to ask the people of the rainforest for food and permission to cross their land. Many of them came to meet him and helped guide him through the most difficult terrain. As he walked Ed wrote a blog, recording his day-to-day experiences. He used the media interest in his trip to protest about the destruction of the rainforest and raise money for environmental and children's charities in Brazil and Peru.

simplified: Companies have learned that the sharing economy can make money. They want to use things that people don't use much. Many companies now make websites that help customers find people who can give them products or services. Companies like Airbnb help people make money from empty rooms in their houses. They can rent these rooms to visitors. Uber is another example. It helps people use their cars like taxis to make extra money when they have free time.
original: Businesses have caught on to the profitability of the sharing economy and are seeking to gain from making use of those underutilised resources. A business model that has rapidly risen in popularity sees companies providing an online platform that puts customers in contact with those who can provide a particular product or service. Companies like Airbnb act as a middleman for people to cash in on their unused rooms and houses and let them out as lucrative accommodation. Another example is Uber, which encourages people to use their own personal cars as taxis to make some extra cash in their free time.

simplified: One of the most important jobs of zoos today is helping animals have babies, especially animals that might disappear forever. In nature, some very rare animals have trouble finding other animals to have babies with. They might also be in danger from people who hunt them illegally, losing their homes, and other animals that want to eat them. A good zoo will let these animals live and have babies in a safe place. Also, when there are fewer wild animals, there is more danger that all the animals become too similar to each other. Baby-making programs help with this problem: animals born in zoos can go back to nature to make the animal groups more different from each other.
original: One of the most important modern functions of zoos is supporting international breeding programmes, particularly for endangered species. In the wild, some of the rarest species have difficulty in finding mates and breeding, and they might also be threatened by poachers, loss of their habitat and predators. A good zoo will enable these species to live and breed in a secure environment. In addition, as numbers of some wild species drop, there is an increased danger of populations becoming too genetically similar. Breeding programmes provide a safeguard: zoo-bred animals can be released into the wild to increase genetic diversity.

simplified: Both of these kinds of accidents do not happen very often, but boats and trains can make a bridge fall down for different reasons. With trains, it's how fast they hit the bridge that can make it fall down. With boats, it's because they are very heavy that can make the bridge fall down, even if they are moving very slowly when it happens. The best way to stop bridges from breaking is to plan for problems before they happen. New technology that can find weak parts of bridges, safer places for workers and better ways to build bridges can all help to stop these terrible accidents.
original: Both of these kinds of accidents are extremely rare, but boats and trains can cause a bridge to collapse for different reasons. With trains, it's the velocity of the impact that can bring a bridge down. With boats, it's the very large mass they have that can bring about the collapse, even if they are moving very slowly when it occurs. The best way to avoid bridge failures is to plan for them. Modern technologies that can detect structural weakness, safer working environments and better designs can all help to reduce these terrible accidents.

simplified: At first, Pi is very scared of the animals and jumps into the sea. Then he remembers that there are hungry sharks in the water around him and knows his only choice is to go back into the lifeboat. One by one, the animals in the lifeboat kill and eat each other, until only Pi and the tiger are left. Luckily for Pi, the tiger, who he calls Richard Parker, feels sick from the boat moving and does not want to eat him right now.
original: At first, Pi is terrified of the animals and jumps into the ocean. Then he remembers that there are hungry sharks in the water around him and realises his only option is to climb back into the lifeboat. One by one, the animals in the lifeboat kill and eat each other, till only Pi and the tiger are left. Fortunately for Pi, the tiger, who he names Richard Parker, is seasick and has no immediate interest in eating him.

simplified: When Pi is 16, a new government comes to power. His parents don't like this government. They are worried about the future, so they decide to close their zoo and move to Canada. They sell some animals to zoos in North America. The family travels by ship to Canada with the other animals. During the trip, there is a big storm and the ship goes down. Pi's family and all the sailors die in the water. But Pi gets into a small boat with a hyena, zebra, orang-utan and a very big tiger.
original: When Pi is 16, a new government is elected that his parents don't support. Worried about the future, Pi's parents decide to close the zoo and emigrate to Canada. Some of the animals are sold to zoos in North America and the family travel by ship to Canada taking the animals with them. On the way, there is a terrible storm and the ship sinks. Tragically, Pi's family and the ship's sailors all drown, but Pi finds himself in a lifeboat with a hyena, zebra, orang-utan and an enormous tiger.

simplified: The Hunger Games is a very popular book for teenagers and young people. An American writer called Suzanne Collins wrote it. The book came out in 2008. Now people can read it in 26 different languages and millions of people around the world have bought it. It was also the first book for young people that sold more than a million copies on computers and phones. Hollywood made The Hunger Games into a big movie and the movie is very successful too. In the first weekend, the movie made 152.5 million dollars just in North America!
original: The Hunger Games is a hugely successful book for teenagers and young adults by the American author Suzanne Collins. Since it was published in 2008 it has been translated into 26 different languages and has sold millions of copies around the world. It is also the first book for young readers to sell more than a million electronic copies. The Hunger Games is now a major Hollywood film and is just as successful. It made 152.5 million dollars in its opening weekend in North America alone!

simplified: Maybe dreams happen because our mind puts together the thoughts we have during the day, but they show up in dreams with special meanings. When we're awake, our thoughts usually come to our minds as words, like talking to ourselves. But when we're asleep, the part of our brain that controls language works less while the part that controls feelings works more.
original: Maybe dreams are the result of our mind organising the thoughts we have during the day, but they appear in dreams with symbolic meaning. When we're awake, our thoughts mostly appear in our minds as words, like conversations we have with ourselves. But when we're asleep, the part of our brain that controls language becomes less active while the part that controls emotions becomes more active.

simplified: Good relationships are very important for happiness. In one study, happy people had strong connections with friends and family. They spent time with them often. You need at least one person to talk about your personal feelings with. Just one person is enough for deep conversations, plus other friends too. It's not enough to have many friends just for activities or to talk about music or sports. That deeper connection is very important. Some people need to learn how to listen well to others to make stronger relationships.
original: Having good relationships is a big part of being happy. In one study, most happy people were found to have strong ties to friends and family and they made sure they spent time with them regularly. You also need at least one person who you discuss personal feelings with – called 'self-disclosure'. Just one person for a heart-to-heart is enough, together with a network of other relationships. It's not enough to have lots of friends just to do things with or chat to about music or football. That deeper connection is all-important. Some people need to learn how to listen effectively to others in order to develop stronger relationships.

simplified: Carol Dweck is a psychologist who talks about 'growth mindset'. She says our brain can change and we can learn new skills. We can get better at things we were not good at before. Many people like to praise the final result and natural talents. For example, they say 'You are really good at seeing small things' or 'You are very good at planning parties'. But research shows something different. When we praise how people do things - when we praise their hard work, trying new things, and how they solve problems - we help them learn new skills. This also helps them get better at things they already know how to do.
original: Psychologist and 'growth mindset' proponent Carol Dweck spoke of the plasticity of the brain and our ability to develop skills and talents that we might not have been good at to start with. Many of us tend to focus our praise on the end result and seemingly innate talents, e.g. 'You really have an eye for details' or 'You have a real talent for organising events'. However, research suggests that by focusing on the process of how things are done – praising effort, experimentation and problem-solving strategies – we can encourage the development of new skills and the continued honing of talents.

simplified: The rover checks the air around it from time to time, and in 2014 it found the air had another very simple organic molecule that is an important part of natural gas: methane. Organic molecules are chemicals that contain carbon and are found in living things. One thing about methane is that it only lasts a few hundred years. This means that something, somewhere on Mars, is making new methane all the time. NASA says Mars sends out thousands of tons of methane at once. The amount of methane goes up and down at different times of the year, almost like the planet is breathing it.
original: The rover analyses the air around it periodically, and in 2014 it found the air contained another of the most basic organic molecules and a key ingredient of natural gas: methane. One of the characteristics of methane is that it only survives a few hundred years. This means that something, somewhere on Mars, is replenishing the supply. According to NASA, Mars emits thousands of tons of methane at a time. The level of methane rises and falls at seasonal intervals in the year, almost as if the planet is breathing it.

simplified: Early in her work, a scientist named Carol Dweck from Stanford University gave a group of ten-year-old children problems that were a little too difficult for them. One group had a good reaction. They said they loved the challenge and understood that they could get better at things. She says they had a 'growth mindset' - this means they believe they can learn and improve. They think about what they can do in the future. But another group of children felt that someone was testing how smart they were and they had failed. They had a 'fixed mindset' - this means they believe they cannot change or get better. They could not imagine getting better at things. Some of these children said they might cheat next time. Others looked for someone who did worse than them to feel better about themselves.
original: Early in her career, the psychologist Carol Dweck of Stanford University gave a group of ten-year-olds problems that were slightly too hard for them. One group reacted positively, said they loved challenge and understood that their abilities could be developed. She says they had a 'growth mindset' and are focused on what they can achieve in the future. But another group of children felt that their intelligence was being judged and they had failed. They had a 'fixed mindset' and were unable to imagine improving. Some of these children said they might cheat in the future; others looked for someone who had done worse than them to boost their self-esteem.

simplified: Horror films love empty places where no people live. This could be an old hospital that nobody uses, a scary empty house or a town with no people. There's something special about lonely, empty places. What was it like when people lived there? Why did they go away? Maybe it's also because they are so quiet, and this can be very scary too. Of course, empty places are also good for horror film directors because it's easy to believe that your phone will not work there either.
original: Horror films love uninhabited places. This could be an abandoned hospital, a scary empty house or a ghost town. There's something about lonely, empty places. What was it like when people lived there? Why did they leave? Maybe it's also that they are so quiet, which can be very scary too. Of course, abandoned places are also handy for horror film directors in that it's more believable that you will have no phone coverage there either.

simplified: No matter what kind of house it is, the basement is a scary place in horror movies. That's usually where something is hiding or where the bad crazy person has put their things. Basements are always dark and often wet. You can only get to them by going down narrow stairs. And basements are always frightening, even when there isn't anything down there.
original: No matter what kind of house it is, the basement is a scary place in horror films. That's usually where something is hiding or where the evil psychopath has hidden their tools. Basements are always dark and often damp. You can only reach them by a narrow staircase. And basements are always creepy, even when there isn't anything down there.

simplified: Gary Collins was a policeman who was not working. He was watching the London riots on TV. He quickly saw several people he knew and stopped his holiday early to help find out who they were. He spent six months looking at security camera videos and found 190 people. He could tell who many people were just by looking at their eyes. His help was very important for the police work. Even with 200,000 hours of video, computer programs that recognize faces could only find one person.
original: Gary Collins, an off-duty policeman, was watching the London riots on TV. He immediately recognised several people and cut his holiday short to help with identification. He ended up spending six months going through the CCTV film and managed to identify 190 people, many from their eyes alone. His help was of decisive importance in the investigation. Even with 200,000 hours of footage, facial recognition software managed to identify just one person.

simplified: I think it's really interesting to think about how we will make ourselves better and change faster as humans by adding things to our bodies. Think about putting a small computer inside our brain! Soon we will be able to do this and make our math skills better, help us see and hear better, and improve our memory. This idea will become normal for more and more people.
original: Personally, I think it's fascinating to consider how we'll speed up our evolution as a species by augmenting our bodies. Imagine if you could implant a computer inside our brain! Soon we'll be able to do just that and enhance our mathematical ability, audiovisual perception and our memory, and this idea is only going to become more and more commonplace.

simplified: It was a very interesting talk and the speaker was really right about some things. Think about how parents affect their children, for example. How can we expect teenagers not to send messages while doing their homework when they see their parents writing on Facebook while cooking dinner or waiting at traffic lights? She also made a good point about people wanting to be in two or more places at the same time. So they go back and forth between their real conversations and online conversations. I see it all the time with my teenage daughter and her friends. They plan to meet and then sit together without talking while each one has a different conversation online.
original: It was a fascinating talk and the speaker really hit the nail on the head with a couple of things. Take parental influence, for instance. How can we expect teenagers not to text while doing their homework when they witness their parents posting on social media while cooking the evening meal or waiting at a red light? She also made a valid point about people wanting to be in two or several places at once. So they switch back and forth between their real-life and online conversations.
